fields.Transcription: Merheba, dembaş. Navê min Şilovan e û ez niha bi Kurdî ya Kurmancî diaxivim. Kurdî ya Kurmancî zaravekî ji pênc zaravên zimanê Kurdî ye û Kurdên ku li bakûrê Kurdistanê û li Rojavayê Kurdistanê ev zarav diaxivin û Kurdên ku li Başûrê Kurdistanê û Rojhilatê Kurdistanê bi Soranî diaxivin. Yan pirtirîn yanî. Bes Kurdên ku bi Kurmancî biaxivin li wir jî hene. Ez bi xwe fêrî zimanê zelal, fêrî ev zimanê Kurmancî bi tenê bûm. Ji ber ku li Sûryê -ez ji Sûryê hatime, Rojavayê Kurdistanê- li wê de zimanê Kurdî qedexe bû. Yanî tu nikare bi zimanê xwe fêr bibe. Ehm.. niha ez li Elmanyayê dijîm. Li bajarê Kolnê û weke penaber hatim Elmanya. Ehm.. li salê 2015 ehm.. belê. Û Kurmancî yanî.. ez hîn çi bêjim.. Kurmancî zimanekî gelekî xweş e. Ez ji vê zimanî gelekî, zehf, zor hezdikim û dixwazim ku rojekî were, ku ev qedexebûn li ser wê rabe. Yanî her kes ku Kurd yan jî ne Kurd jî, karibe vê zimanî fêr bibe, binivîse û biaxive. Li her der. Ew daxwaza min e. Û weke din, sipasîya we hemîya dikim, sipasîya hemo temaşavanên vî vîdîyoyê dikim û daxwaza min ku hûn bi xêrê û bi şahîyê bimînin. Bi xatirê we.
fields.Translation: English: Hello, good day! My name is Shlovan and I’m now speaking with the Kurmanji Kurdish. The Kurmanji Kurdish is one of the five Kurdish dialects. The Kurds of North Kurdistan(Turkey) and West Kurdistan(Syria) speak this dialect and the Kurds in South Kurdistan(Iraq) and East Kurdistan(Iran) speak Sorani Kurdish. Well most of them, but there are Kurds that speak Kurmanji there too. I learned the pure language, this language, Kurmanji alone because in Syria -I come from Syria, Rojava(West Kurdistan)- where the Kurdish language was banned. Like you can’t learn in your own language. Erm... now I live in Germany, the city of Cologne. I came here as a refugee, erm… in 2015, erm… yeah. And Kurmanji Kurdish -like what I else have to say- Kurmanji is a very beautiful tongue. I love it so so so much and I wish that it will be no more banned, that every Kurd -or even not Kurd- be able to learn this language, write and speak with it everywhere. This is my wish. Otherwise, I thank everyone, thanks to everyone, who is watching this video and I wish you a happy life. Bye.
fields.Video Description:
This video was recorded by Mohamad Saeed in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany. Northern Kurdish, also known as Kurmanji, is largely spoken in southeast Turkey, northwest Iran, northern Iraq, northern Syria, and the Caucasus and Khorasan regions by the Kurdish people. The Kurds are a stateless group, meaning they do not possess a state of their own and are considered a minority ethnic group within Iran, which explains the wide distribution of the Kurdish language. It is the most spoken form of Kurdish -- the other Kurdish varieties are Sorani, Southern Kurdish, and Laki. Kurmanji itself is incredibly diverse, forming a dialect continuum containing six recognized dialects: Northwestern Kurmanji, Southwestern Kurmanji, Northern Kurmanji, Southern Kurmanji, Southeastern Kurmanji, and Anatolian Kurmanji. The earliest Kurmanji records date back to around the 16th century and include the works of prominent poets like Ahmad Khani. Kurmanji is also the chosen ceremonial language of Yazidis. The Kurdish languages that form the Kurdish continuum are together an official language of Iraq alongside Arabic, a regional language of Iran, and a minority language of Armenia.

Northern Kurdish was spoken by roughly 20 million people worldwide as of 2009, but that number is thought to be decreasing. Northern Kurdish belongs to the Indo-Iranian branch of the Indo-European language family.
Demographics: 15,000,000 in Turkey (McCarus 2009), decreasing. Very provisional figures for Northern Kurdish speaker population. Population total all countries: 20,210,890. 3,000,000 monolinguals. Especially in Hakkari and Shirnak provinces.
